questions.question_text: Which of the following should a technician investigate when using a network baseline to troubleshoot?

choices.B: Determining if the server performance is degraded.
choices.C: Changes that have been made to the network configuration.
choices.A: Tracing a network wire connectivity issue from the datacenter to a host.
choices.D: Location of networking equipment in a rack.

comments.content: answer C works just as well as B in regards to mr. meyer's statement...

discussion.content:
Answer B is correct. This is on Mike Meyer's book: 

Baselines
The only way to know when a problem is brewing on your network
is to know how things perform when allâ€™s well with the network.
Part of any proper performance monitor is the facility to create a
baseline: a log of performance indicators such as CPU usage,
network utilization, and other values to give you a picture of your
network and servers when they are working correctly. A major
change in these values can point to problems on a server or the
network as a whole.

comments.content: It says 'baseline' so when baseline is stated what should be the consideration? It's performance right?
You can investigate if there has been degradation by referring to the baseline. So it is an investigation - just to determine any change, not necessarily why the change has occurred.

discussion.content: How can you "investigate" "determining if server performance has degraded"? That doesn't even work as a sentence. You can investigate "changes" though.

The performance being degraded is what would be found out by comparing current performance to the baseline, sure.

BUT when you use terminology like "Which of the following should the technician investigate..." well the technician should investigate whether or not changes have been made to the network configuration that could be effecting its current performance.

The answer is C based off of the wording of the question. If this question was written with the intention of B being the answer, this question was written by an idiot.
Whoever wrote this question and the proceeding answers needs to go back to English class
"If server performance has degraded" is a better worded answer. And I agree, even the question itself could be worded better. I'm guessing Indians write the questions these days.
It says "network baseline" - not system or server baseline. So server performance is only a factor in the "network baseline" not the main focus. Hence the right answer is "C".

choices.A: Disable the broadcasting of the SSID.
choices.B: Enable WPA2 authentication for all hosts.
choices.C: Use private addressing for the DHCP scope.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to upgrade a SOHO wireless router's firmware. The technician resets the router to factory settings and installs the new firmware. The technician enters the DHCP information and sets the SSID. Which of the following configurations would provide the MOST protection from advance hackers?

discussion.content: He should also Make sure the default username and password are changed :)

comments.content:
good point, but a key part of the question is "advanced hacker"
WPA2 is crackable but only by brute force. so it won't stop an advanced hacker 100% but it will slow them down significantly.

questions.question_text: A technician notices clients are receiving a 169.254.x.x IP address following the upgrade of a server. Which of the following ports should the technician check on the local server firewall?

discussion.content: Addresses starting with 169.x.x.x are APIPA addresses. APIPA addresses are assigned when DHCP fails to assign an address first. Ports 67 and 68 are DHCP ports that need to be turned on for DHCP to work. So yeah, B.
An IP address that starts with 169 means that the host failed to obtain a dynamic IP from a DHCP server. Ports 67 and 68 are the port numbers for DHCP server, DHCP client so yeah answer is B.
So I guessed B. But I'm a little confused about the term "receiving".

comments.content: they were "given" that IP, it can be interpreted that way aka something related to DHCP

questions.question_text: Which of the following datacenter security methodologies is MOST likely to remain usable during a network outage?

discussion.content:
Door locks is the most correct answer. No level of network outage will ever impact a traditional door and lock.
All other answers may rely on network resources or reporting mechanisms that could be compromised or delayed in the event of a network outage.

comments.content: Please re-read my sentence, it is incorrect IF it uses a software or hardware technology yet it doesn't use any of those technology then Door Lock is correct. Lol

discussion.content:
Comptia: if the sky is orange and your facing north west what kind of IP is used to access the stars.
Also Comptia: when the power is out which of these security features is going to be available.

comments.content: This comment made my entire weekend!

discussion.content:
Comptia: is the sky is purple and you are facing northeast which stars are yellow 
also Comptia: If the power is out which of these security features will still work.
Totally door locks. I work in a data center and there have been times when we lose connection to our readers so the only way you can access a certain room is with a key.
too many IFs.... over complicate the simple questions

comments.content: Partly I am but door lock is an incorrect answer only...IF...the lock is involved with the software and hardware technology that will shutdown the lock due to loss of power. Since the door lock has no capability of this technology then Door Lock is the right choice. Sorry, I am just testing how our brain works with the reading comprehension.
YouDipEE got me laughing in my seat! :'D

discussion.content: Door lock is incorrect IF this lock uses a software and hardware technology.

questions.question_text: A network technician is implementing a solution on the network to hide the workstation internal IP addresses across a WAN. Which of the following is the technician configuring?

discussion.content: Network address translation (NAT), don't forget it makes private IP's into a pubic one (personal network to the internet). While Port address translation does very similar things, making private IP's into public IP's but with the help of ports.
